cards.back: Frontend: what users see (UI), runs in browser, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, React/Vue. Backend: behind-the-scenes logic and data, runs on server, handles database/auth. Frontend is the restaurant dining room, backend is the kitchen.

An app with both frontend and backend, often built together. Full-stack developer works on both. Common combos: React + Node.js, Next.js, Django. When talking to LLMs: "Build a full-stack app with React frontend and Express backend"

Servers owned by AWS, Google, Azure that you rent instead of buying. Benefits: no hardware to maintain, scale as needed, pay for what you use. Services include servers, databases, storage, ML. When talking to LLMs: "Deploy the app to AWS"

Making your app available on the internet. Steps: build code, upload to server, configure domain, start app. Platforms: Vercel, Netlify, Heroku, AWS. When talking to LLMs: "How do I deploy this to Vercel?"

A package with your app and everything it needs to run. "Works on my machine" becomes "works everywhere". Like a shipping container - standardized box that goes on any truck/ship. When talking to LLMs: "Create a Dockerfile for this app"

Breaking an app into small independent services that each do one thing. Example: user service, order service, payment service. Opposite of monolith. When talking to LLMs: "Should this be a microservice or part of the main app?"

A single unified application where all features are in one codebase. Pros: simpler to develop/deploy, easier to debug. Cons: harder to scale parts, one bug can break everything. When talking to LLMs: "We have a monolith - how should we structure it?"

Content Delivery Network - servers worldwide that cache content closer to users. Benefits: faster loads, reduced server load, better reliability. Great for images, videos, static sites. Examples: Cloudflare, CloudFront.

Running code without managing servers. Upload function, cloud runs it when triggered, pay only when it runs. Examples: AWS Lambda, Vercel Functions. Good for APIs, scheduled tasks. When talking to LLMs: "Create a serverless function to process uploads"

Configuration values stored outside code, especially secrets. Examples: DATABASE_URL, API_KEY, NODE_ENV. Keep secrets out of code, change settings per environment. When talking to LLMs: "Store the API key in an environment variable"

Development: your local machine. Staging: test copy mimicking production. Production: live app users access. Separate environments let you test safely before affecting users. When talking to LLMs: "Works in dev but breaks in production"

Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment - automating testing and deployment. CI: auto-run tests on push. CD: auto-deploy when tests pass. Tools: GitHub Actions, GitLab CI. When talking to LLMs: "Set up CI to run tests on every pull request"

cards.front: What is an SPA (Single Page Application)?
cards.back: A web app that loads once and updates dynamically without full page reloads. Click link → JavaScript updates content (no reload). Built with React, Vue, Angular. When talking to LLMs: "Build an SPA with React"

Generating HTML on the server before sending to browser. Benefits: better SEO, faster initial load. Trade-off: more server work. Frameworks: Next.js, Nuxt. When talking to LLMs: "Use SSR for blog pages for better SEO"

Distributes traffic across multiple servers so none get overwhelmed. Like having multiple checkout lines with someone directing customers to the shortest. Benefits: handle more traffic, if one server dies others continue.

cards.front: What is horizontal vs vertical scaling?
cards.back: Vertical: bigger server (more CPU/RAM) - simple but has limits. Horizontal: more servers - scales infinitely but needs load balancer. Vertical = bigger pizza, Horizontal = more pizzas. When talking to LLMs: "Scale horizontally for Black Friday traffic"

A line of tasks waiting to be processed. User uploads video → "process video" added to queue → respond immediately → worker processes in background. Tools: RabbitMQ, SQS, Redis. When talking to LLMs: "Add email sending to a queue"
Sits between internet and your servers. Uses: load balancing, SSL termination, caching, security. Examples: Nginx, Cloudflare. When talking to LLMs: "Set up Nginx as a reverse proxy"

Domain Name System - translates domain names to IP addresses. mysite.com → 192.168.1.1. Like a phone book for the internet. A record: domain → IP. CNAME: domain → another domain. When talking to LLMs: "Point the DNS to the new server"

A single repository containing multiple projects. Example: /apps/web, /apps/api, /packages/shared all in one repo. Benefits: shared code, consistent tooling, atomic changes. Tools: Turborepo, Nx. When talking to LLMs: "Set up a monorepo with shared components"
